speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: They say miracles are past; and we have our

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it that

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: into seeming knowledge, when we should submit

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: ourselves to an unknown fear.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: shot out in our latter times.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And so 'tis.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: To be relinquish'd of the artists,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: So I say.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: So I say.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Right; so I say.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: That gave him out incurable,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Not to be helped,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Right; as 'twere, a man assured of a--

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Uncertain life, and sure death.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Just, you say well; so would I have said.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, you

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: shall read it in--what do you call there?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: That's it; I would have said the very same.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: 'fore me,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I speak in respect--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange, that is the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a most

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the--

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Very hand of heaven.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ay, so I say.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: In a most weak--

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: pausing

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: and debile minister, great power, great

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: transcendence: which should, indeed, give us a

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: further use to be made than alone the recovery of

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: the king, as to be--

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: pausing

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: generally thankful.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the king.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll like a maid the

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: better, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why, he's

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: able to lead her a coranto.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: 'Fore God, I think so.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Go, call before me all the lords in court.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;

speaker: KING
text_entry: And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou hast repeal'd, a second time receive

speaker: KING
text_entry: The confirmation of my promised gift,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Which but attends thy naming.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Enter three or four Lords

speaker: KING
text_entry: Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,

speaker: KING
text_entry: O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice

speaker: KING
text_entry: I have to use: thy frank election make;

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Fall, when Love please! marry, to each, but one!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: My mouth no more were broken than these boys',

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: And writ as little beard.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Peruse them well:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Not one of those but had a noble father.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Gentlemen,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.

speaker: All
text_entry: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That I protest I simply am a maid.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Please it your majesty, I have done already:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: 'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We'll ne'er come there again.'

speaker: KING
text_entry: Make choice; and, see,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And to imperial Love, that god most high,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And grant it.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: for my life.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Before I speak, too threateningly replies:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Love make your fortunes twenty times above

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Her that so wishes and her humble love!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: No better, if you please.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: My wish receive,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I'd have them whipped; or I would send them to the

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Turk, to make eunuchs of.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Be not afraid that I your hand should take;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I'll never do you wrong for your own sake:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have her:

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: sure, they are bastards to the English; the French

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: ne'er got 'em.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You are too young, too happy, and too good,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To make yourself a son out of my blood.

speaker: Fourth Lord
text_entry: Fair one, I think not so.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunk

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: wine: but if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youth

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: of fourteen; I have known thee already.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: [To BERTRAM]  I dare not say I take you; but I give

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Me and my service, ever whilst I live,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Into your guiding power. This is the man.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: In such a business give me leave to use

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: The help of mine own eyes.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Know'st thou not, Bertram,

speaker: KING
text_entry: What she has done for me?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Yes, my good lord;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But never hope to know why I should marry her.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Must answer for your raising? I know her well:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: She had her breeding at my father's charge.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Rather corrupt me ever!

speaker: KING
text_entry: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which

speaker: KING
text_entry: I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off

speaker: KING
text_entry: In differences so mighty. If she be

speaker: KING
text_entry: All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest,

speaker: KING
text_entry: A poor physician's daughter, thou dislikest

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of virtue for the name: but do not so:

speaker: KING
text_entry: From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,

speaker: KING
text_entry: The place is dignified by the doer's deed:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,

speaker: KING
text_entry: It is a dropsied honour. Good alone

speaker: KING
text_entry: Is good without a name. Vileness is so:

speaker: KING
text_entry: The property by what it is should go,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;

speaker: KING
text_entry: In these to nature she's immediate heir,

speaker: KING
text_entry: And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Which challenges itself as honour's born

speaker: KING
text_entry: And is not like the sire: honours thrive,

speaker: KING
text_entry: When rather from our acts we them derive

speaker: KING
text_entry: Than our foregoers: the mere word's a slave

speaker: KING
text_entry: Debosh'd on every tomb, on every grave

speaker: KING
text_entry: A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb

speaker: KING
text_entry: Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said?

speaker: KING
text_entry: If thou canst like this creature as a maid,

speaker: KING
text_entry: I can create the rest: virtue and she

speaker: KING
text_entry: Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Let the rest go.

speaker: KING
text_entry: My honour's at the stake; which to defeat,

speaker: KING
text_entry: I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift;

speaker: KING
text_entry: That dost in vile misprision shackle up

speaker: KING
text_entry: My love and her desert; that canst not dream,

speaker: KING
text_entry: We, poising us in her defective scale,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know,

speaker: KING
text_entry: It is in us to plant thine honour where

speaker: KING
text_entry: We please to have it grow. Cheque thy contempt:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Obey our will, which travails in thy good:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Believe not thy disdain, but presently

speaker: KING
text_entry: Do thine own fortunes that obedient right

speaker: KING
text_entry: Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;

speaker: KING
text_entry: Or I will throw thee from my care for ever

speaker: KING
text_entry: Into the staggers and the careless lapse

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate

speaker: KING
text_entry: Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My fancy to your eyes: when I consider

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: What great creation and what dole of honour

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: The praised of the king; who, so ennobled,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Is as 'twere born so.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Take her by the hand,

speaker: KING
text_entry: And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise

speaker: KING
text_entry: A counterpoise, if not to thy estate

speaker: KING
text_entry: A balance more replete.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I take her hand.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Good fortune and the favour of the king

speaker: KING
text_entry: Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony

speaker: KING
text_entry: Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,

speaker: KING
text_entry: And be perform'd to-night: the solemn feast

speaker: KING
text_entry: Shall more attend upon the coming space,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: [Advancing]  Do you hear, monsieur? a word with you.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Your pleasure, sir?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Your lord and master did well to make his

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: recantation.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Recantation! My lord! my master!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Ay; is it not a language I speak?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: bloody succeeding. My master!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: To what is count's man: count's master is of

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: another style.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too old.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to which

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: title age cannot bring thee.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent of thy

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: travel; it might pass: yet the scarfs and the

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: believing thee a vessel of too great a burthen. I

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: have now found thee; when I lose thee again, I care

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: not: yet art thou good for nothing but taking up; and

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: that thou't scarce worth.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee,--

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: hasten thy trial; which if--Lord have mercy on thee

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: for a hen! So, my good window of lattice, fare thee

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: well: thy casement I need not open, for I look

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: through thee. Give me thy hand.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Yes, good faith, every dram of it; and I will not

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: bate thee a scruple.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Well, I shall be wiser.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: a smack o' the contrary. If ever thou be'st bound

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: to be proud of thy bondage. I have a desire to hold

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: that I may say in the default, he is a man I know.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I would it were hell-pains for thy sake, and my poor

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: doing eternal: for doing I am past: as I will by

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thee, in what motion age will give me leave.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: be patient; there is no fettering of authority.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I'll beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: any convenience, an he were double and double a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: lord. I'll have no more pity of his age than I

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: would of--I'll beat him, an if I could but meet him again.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Re-enter LAFEU

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's news

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: for you: you have a new mistress.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: some reservation of your wrongs: he is my good

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: lord: whom I serve above is my master.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Who? God?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ay, sir.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: The devil it is that's thy master. Why dost thou

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: garter up thy arms o' this fashion? dost make hose of

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: sleeves? do other servants so? Thou wert best set

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thy lower part where thy nose stands. By mine

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'ld beat

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thee: methinks, thou art a general offence, and

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: every man should beat thee: I think thou wast

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking a

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: kernel out of a pomegranate; you are a vagabond and

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: no true traveller: you are more saucy with lords

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: and honourable personages than the commission of your

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You are not

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: worth another word, else I'ld call you knave. I leave you.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Good, very good; it is so then: good, very good;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: let it be concealed awhile.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Re-enter BERTRAM

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What's the matter, sweet-heart?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I will not bed her.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What, what, sweet-heart?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: O my Parolles, they have married me!

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: The tread of a man's foot: to the wars!

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: There's letters from my mother: what the import is,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I know not yet.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ay, that would be known. To the wars, my boy, to the wars!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: He wears his honour in a box unseen,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Spending his manly marrow in her arms,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Which should sustain the bound and high curvet

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Therefore, to the war!

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: It shall be so: I'll send her to my house,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And wherefore I am fled; write to the king

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: That which I durst not speak; his present gift

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Shall furnish me to those Italian fields,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Where noble fellows strike: war is no strife

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: To the dark house and the detested wife.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Will this capriccio hold in thee? art sure?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Go with me to my chamber, and advise me.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I'll send her straight away: to-morrow

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: A young man married is a man that's marr'd:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: The king has done you wrong: but, hush, 'tis so.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exeunt
